name: Crunchy Chili Oil
description: Crispy, crunchy, rich chili oil that adds fantastic flavor to noodles, dumplings, and many other dishes. Seriously versatile and a must have condiment in the fridge.
keywords: Crunchy Chili Oil, Asian, Condiment, Oil, Scallions, Garlic, Ginger, Orange peel, Cayenne peppers, Sichuan peppercorns, Star anise, Cinnamon stick, Bay leaf, Cardamom, Chili flakes, Sugar, MSG, Salt, Sesame oil, Light soy sauce, Gochujang, Doubanjang, Fried shallots, Fried garlic chips, Roasted peanuts, Toasted sesame seeds

Â½ cup Chili Flakes of choice

recipeInstructions.text: Slice the shallots and garlic (ones for frying) very thinly. Heat oil in a wide shallow pot or pan and fry the shallots until golden brown. Strain the oil and place the shallots on a paper towel-lined plate. Repeat the same process with the garlic.
recipeInstructions.name: Fry Shallots and Garlic

recipeInstructions.text: Place the aromatics (scallions, garlic, ginger, orange peel, cayenne peppers, Sichuan peppercorns, star anise, cinnamon stick, bay leaf, cardamom) into the oil in the pot or pan. Infuse the oil with the flavors over low heat for about 1 hour, maintaining a steady temperature of 110-120Â°C.
recipeInstructions.name: Infuse Oil with Aromatics

recipeInstructions.text: In a separate heat-safe bowl, combine chili flakes, white sugar, MSG, peanuts, sesame seeds, soy sauce, gochujang and salt.
recipeInstructions.name: Combine Dry Ingredients

recipeInstructions.text: Increase the heat of the oil to 120-150Â°C. Pour the hot oil over the chili flake mixture, stirring to mix everything thoroughly.
recipeInstructions.name: Pour Hot Oil over Chili Flakes

recipeInstructions.text: Stir in sesame oil, fried shallots and fried garlic chips.
recipeInstructions.name: Add Remaining Ingredients

recipeInstructions.text: Once the mixture has cooled sufficiently, taste for seasoning (add more salt if required), transfer it to a sterile jar and store in the fridge. Use the crunchy chili oil as a flavorful condiment on various dishes.
recipeInstructions.name: Cool and Store

notes: It goes well with noodles, dumplings, fried eggs, burgers, pasta, curry, breads and many other dishes. Feel free to customize the flavors by adding or removing ingredients to suit your taste, there is so much flavor a little here or a less there is alright.
Keeps in the fridge for a few weeks. If it starts to bubble or taste off then don't consume.
To avoid faffing about in the first step and getting crispy garlic and shallot bits, you can just get some from an asian grocer. So much easier and far less likely to burn things.
